image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: After a brief downturn earlier in the year, Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode, with CoreLogic data showing house prices increased for a sixth consecutive month in August.

title.children: Canberrans encouraged to have their say on proposed four options to ban phones in schools

image.altText: A woman in pink shirt standing in city street.

items.synopsis: Young culturally diverse Australians continue to face discrimination when trying to find work, according to recent studies. Experts found non-Anglo Australians struggle to get a job interview, despite being well qualified, and some are altering their identities on paper to get a fair go.

title.children: If you're a graduate with an English-sounding name, you may be closer to securing a job than some of your peers

image.altText: Two men with greying hair in suits shake hands on a street watched by other people

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bureau of Meteorology is forecasting above average temperatures for most of Australia this spring. Its figures also show the country has likely just had its warmest winter on record. Senior Meteorologist Angus Hines says Australia should expect warm days and nights in the months ahead. "That really warm winter is really providing a bit of a springboard into spring and we're expecting to see by and large more of the same," he said. "The trend is singing out very strongly in regards to temperatures over the coming months that we are again going to see significantly above-average temperatures across the vast majority of Australia." He says the warmer weather will bring with it an increased fire danger. "People around the country, particulary in those fire-prone areas, are urged to assist and update their fire plan and get prepared for what could be a big fire season," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Warm winter recorded, above average temperatures forecast for spring

He says the warmer weather will bring with it an increased fire danger.
"People around the country, particulary in those fire-prone areas, are urged to assist and update their fire plan and get prepared for what could be a big fire season," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Rock band Dire Straits has paid tribute to its guitarist Jack Sonnie on Twitter, saying "Rest in Peace". The band Dire Straits Legacy, which Sonni was part of alongside musicians who recorded and toured with Dire Straits, paid tribute to the star on Facebook. "Our beloved Jack has left a void in our heart and soul … 
we will miss you so much, 
you are forever with us," the band said. Three days ago, Dire Straits Legacy shared with fans that Sonni would not be able to participate in upcoming gigs due to "health problems". The cause of his death has not been reported and a statement from his family has not been released.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dire Straits pays tribute to guitarist Jack Sonni

children.content: Rock band Dire Straits has paid tribute to its guitarist Jack Sonnie on Twitter, saying "Rest in Peace".
The band Dire Straits Legacy, which Sonni was part of alongside musicians who recorded and toured with Dire Straits, paid tribute to the star on Facebook.

"Our beloved Jack has left a void in our heart and soul … 
we will miss you so much, 
you are forever with us," the band said.
Three days ago, Dire Straits Legacy shared with fans that Sonni would not be able to participate in upcoming gigs due to "health problems".
The cause of his death has not been reported and a statement from his family has not been released.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukraine has told critics of the pace of its three-month-old counteroffensive to "shut up". It's the sharpest signal yet of Kyiv's frustration at leaks from Western officials who say its forces are advancing too slowly. Since launching a much vaunted counteroffensive using many billions of dollars of Western military equipment, Ukraine has recaptured more than a dozen villages but has yet to penetrate Russia's main defences. Ukrainian commanders say they are moving slowly on purpose, degrading Russia's defences and logistics to reduce losses when they finally attack at full strength. Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba told reporters criticising the counter-offensive's pace equalled "spitting into the face of [the] Ukrainian soldier who sacrifices his life every day". "I would recommend all critics to shut up, come to Ukraine and try to liberate one square centimetre by themselves," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ukraine's Foreign Minister tells critics: 'Shut up'

children.content: Ukraine has told critics of the pace of its three-month-old counteroffensive to "shut up".
It's the sharpest signal yet of Kyiv's frustration at leaks from Western officials who say its forces are advancing too slowly.

Since launching a much vaunted counteroffensive using many billions of dollars of Western military equipment, Ukraine has recaptured more than a dozen villages but has yet to penetrate Russia's main defences.
Ukrainian commanders say they are moving slowly on purpose, degrading Russia's defences and logistics to reduce losses when they finally attack at full strength.
Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba told reporters criticising the counter-offensive's pace equalled "spitting into the face of [the] Ukrainian soldier who sacrifices his life every day".

props.alt: Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba speaks to the media

children.content: "I would recommend all critics to shut up, come to Ukraine and try to liberate one square centimetre by themselves," he said.

title.children: ASX tipped to open lower, new housing finance figures set to be released

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mark Butler, the federal Minister for Health, was on ABC News Breakfast this morning. He reminded viewers that millions of Australians will be able to get 60 days' worth of medicine on a single script from today. Some pharmacists opposed this measure and waged an aggressive campaign in the media to stop it happening, but they weren't able to. From today, nearly 100 common medicines listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS ) will have the option of a 60-day prescription. This means many patients can now receive twice the medication for the cost of a single prescription. But that's just the start. The changes are happening in 3 stages over 12 months and will apply to more than 300 medicines once completed on 1 September 2024. You can learn more about the changes here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 60 days of medicine from a single script starts today

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Welcome to the first day of spring. The wattle trees outside my house have been carrying brilliant yellow flowers for a few weeks already. Hopefully we'll see lots of bees in them soon. But to the market. Today's the trading day of the week and the ASX 200 futures suggest Australia's stock market will open lower this morning after Wall Street's major indices lost a bit of ground overnight. Yesterday, the business news cycle was dominated by the news that the ACCC had taken Qantas to court for allegedly advertising and selling tickets to flights the airline had already cancelled. It saw Qantas ' share price lose 2 per cent in value, down 12 cents to $5.91, which wasn't much really. Remember, the airline's share price hit $2.36 a share at the beginning of the pandemic in March 2020, and it's been slowly trending higher since then, in fits and starts. Later this morning, we'll get updated retail trade figures, and new lending indicators, from the Bureau of Statistics. That will give us a little more information about the "health" of economic activity (as old Keynesians would have categorised things, anyway).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market expected to lose ground in early trade
